1. Is the Bible fallible, or not?
 
 2. Is the Bible literally true, or not?
 
 3. Is the value of the Bible dependent on its being literally true, or not?

 1. The bible, and all the many interpretations of it, are fallible. To claim otherwise is to claim that the person who has written the bible/made the interpretation is infallible, which is (as far as I am aware) not something that humans ever are. This is always my issue with people who proclaim an 'absolute truth' - in order for their proclamation to be absolute, the person themselves must be incorruptible (by Satan, if you want to look at it from that point of view) and infallible, which strikes me a little arrogant.
 
 2. This excuses the second answer - the bible (more specifically, large swathes of the Old Testament) is not literally true. Creationism is observably false - simply by seeing the light from stars that have taken millions of years to get here. There is absolutely zero scientific evidence that supports a 8000-year-old earth - the only 'evidence' that creationists have is perceived holes in 'opposing' theories, nothing that supports their own. Why should all of the Bible be literally true? Jesus never put a 'this didn't really happen' disclaimer in his parables...
 
 3. The moral/spiritual value of the Bible is not affected by it's literal truth. Many fiction books provide and support good moral behaviour (R.A. Salvatores Drizzt series, Orson Scott Card's Ender series and Catherine Fisher's Book of the Crow all spring to mind) - and while many others don't, this is not because they are works of fiction. If it turned out Jesus' name was actually Brian (mistranslated many years ago), would that affect the message of the bible?
 The bible does not stand and fall as one. If I say 'My name is Ian and I am a giant koala bear', this doesn't imply that I've got my name wrong. If I take it one step further and say "My name is Ian, I am a giant koala bear, and if I am not a giant koala bear then I am not called Ian" then all this means that two out of my three statements are false.
 
 NB: as you can see from my reply in the other thread, all of this works under the assumption that God has not messed up logic. Just to be consistent.
 NB2: Good couple of threads, Matthew. I like this sort of thinking...
